1 nl i celebrate myself, and sing myself, nl and what i assume you shall assume, nl for every atom belonging to me as good belongs to you. nl i loafe and invite my soul, nl i lean and loafe at my ease observing a spear of summer grass. nl my tongue, every atom of my blood, form'd from this soil, this air, nl born here of parents born here from parents the same, and their parents the same, nl i, now thirty-seven years old in perfect health begin, nl hoping to cease not till death nl creeds and schools in abeyance, nl retiring back a while sufficed at what they are, but never forgotten, nl i harbor for good or bad, i permit to speak at every hazard, nl nature without check with original energy. nl 2 nl houses and rooms are full of perfumes, the shelves are crowded with perfumes, nl i breathe the fragrance myself and know it and like it, nl the distillation would intoxicate me also, but i shall not let it. nl the atmosphere is not a perfume, it has no taste of the distillation, it is odorless, nl it is for my mouth forever, i am in love with it, nl i will go to the bank by the wood and become undisguised and naked, nl i am mad for it to be in contact with me. nl the smoke of my own breath, nl echoes, ripples, buzz'd whispers, love-root, silk-thread, crotch and vine, nl my respiration and inspiration, the beating of my heart, the passing of blood and air through my lungs, nl the sniff of green leaves and dry leaves, and of the shore and dark-color'd sea-rocks, and of hay in the barn, nl the sound of the belch'd words of my voice loos'd to the eddies of the wind, nl a few light kisses, a few embraces, a reaching around of arms, nl the play of shine and shade on the trees as the supple boughs wag, nl the delight alone or in the rush of the streets, or along the fields and hill-sides, nl the feeling of health, the full-noon trill, the song of me rising from bed and meeting the sun. nl have you reckon'd a thousand acres much? have you reckon'd the earth much? nl have you practis'd so long to learn to read? nl have you felt so proud to get at the meaning of poems? nl stop this day and night with me and you shall possess the origin of all poems, nl you shall possess the good of the earth and sun, (there are millions of suns left,) nl you shall no longer take things at second or third hand, nor look through the eyes of the dead, nor feed on the spectres in books, nl you shall not look through my eyes either, nor take things from me, nl you shall listen to all sides and filter them from your self. nl 3 nl i have heard what the talkers were talking, the talk of the nl beginning and the end, nl but i do not talk of the beginning or the end. nl there was never any more inception than there is now, nl nor any more youth or age than there is now, nl and will never be any more perfection than there is now, nl nor any more heaven or hell than there is now. nl urge and urge and urge, nl always the procreant urge of the world. nl out of the dimness opposite equals advance, always substance and increase, always sex, nl always a knit of identity, always distinction, always a breed of life. nl to elaborate is no avail, learn'd and unlearn'd feel that it is so. nl sure as the most certain sure, plumb in the uprights, well nl entretied, braced in the beams, nl stout as a horse, affectionate, haughty, electrical, nl i and this mystery here we stand. nl clear and sweet is my soul, and clear and sweet is all that is nl not my soul. nl lack one lacks both, and the unseen is proved by the seen, nl till that becomes unseen and receives proof in its turn. nl showing the best and dividing it from the worst age vexes age, nl knowing the perfect fitness and equanimity of things, while nl they discuss i am silent, and go bathe and admire myself. nl welcome is every organ and attribute of me, and of any man nl hearty and clean, nl not an inch nor a particle of an inch is vile, and none shall be less familiar than the rest. nl i am satisfied — i see, dance, laugh, sing; nl as the hugging and loving bed-fellow sleeps at my side nl through the night, and withdraws at the peep of the day nl with stealthy tread, nl leaving me baskets cover'd with white towels swelling the nl house with their plenty, nl shall i postpone my acceptation and realization and scream at my eyes, nl that they turn from gazing after and down the road, nl and forthwith cipher and show me to a cent, nl exactly the value of one and exactly the value of two, and nl which is ahead? nl 4 nl trippers and askers surround me, nl people i meet, the effect upon me of my early life or the ward and city i live in, or the nation, nl the latest dates, discoveries, inventions, societies, authors nl old and new, nl my dinner, dress, associates, looks, compliments, dues, nl the real or fancied indifference of some man or woman i love, nl the sickness of one of my folks or of myself, or ill-doing or nl loss or lack of money, or depressions or exaltations, nl battles, the horrors of fratricidal war, the fever of doubtful nl news, the fitful events; nl these come to me days and nights and go from me again, nl but they are not the me myself. nl apart from the pulling and hauling stands what i am, nl stands amused, complacent, compassionating, idle, unitary, nl looks down, is erect, or bends an arm on an impalpable certain rest, nl looking with side-curved head curious what will come next, nl both in and out of the game and watching and wondering at it. nl backward i see in my own days where i sweated through fog with linguists and contenders, nl i have no mockings i receive them the same. nl and now it seems to me the beautiful uncut hair of graves. nl tenderly will i use you curling grass, nl it may be you transpire from the breasts of young men, nl it may be if i had known them i would have loved them, nl it may be you are from old people, or from offspring taken nl soon out of their mothers' laps, nl and here you are the mothers' laps. nl this grass is very dark to be from the white heads of old nl mothers, nl darker than the colourless beards of old men, nl dark to come from under the faint red roofs of mouths. nl o i perceive after all so many 17 nl these are really the thoughts of all men in all ages and lands, nl they are not original with me, nl if they are not yours as much as mine they are nothing, or nl next to nothing, nl if they are rounds and completes all, nl that mystic baffling wonder alone completes all. nl i accept reality and dare not question it, nl materialism first and last imbuing. nl hurrah for positive science! long preparatory to anything else mr bloom brushed off the greater bulk of the shavings and handed stephen the hat and ashplant and bucked him up generally in orthodox samaritan fashion, which he very badly needed. his (stephen's) mind was not exactly what you would call wandering but a bit unsteady and on his expressed desire for some beverage to drink mr bloom, in view of the hour it was and there being no pumps of vartry water available for their ablutions, let alone drinking purposes, hit upon an expedient by suggesting, off the reel, the propriety of the cabman's shelter, as it was called, hardly a stonesthrow away near butt bridge, where they might hit upon some drinkables in the shape of a milk and soda or a mineral. but how to get there was the rub. for the nonce he was rather nonplussed but inasmuch as the duty plainly devolved upon him to take some measures on the subject he pondered suitable ways and means during which stephen repeatedly yawned. so far as he could see he was rather pale in the face so that it occurred to him as highly advisable to get a conveyance of some description which would answer in their then condition, both of them being e. d. ed, particularly stephen, always assuming that there was such a thing to be found. accordingly, after a few such preliminaries, as, in spite of his having forgotten to take up his rather soapsuddy handkerchief after it had done yeoman service in the shaving line, brushing, they both walked together along beaver street, or, more properly, lane, as far as the farrier's and the distinctly fetid atmosphere of the livery stables at the corner of montgomery street where they made tracks to the left from thence debouching into amiens street round by the corner of dan bergin's. but, as he confidently anticipated, there was not a sign of a jehu plying for hire anywhere to be seen except a fourwheeler, probably engaged by some fellows inside on the spree, outside the north star hotel and there was no symptom of its budging a quarter of an inch when mr bloom, who was anything but a professional whistler, endeavoured to hail it by emitting a kind of a whistle, holding his arms arched over his head, twice. nl this was a quandary but, bringing commonsense to bear on it, evidently there was nothing for it but put a good face on the matter and foot it which they accordingly did. so, bevelling around by mullet's and the signal house, which they shortly reached, they proceeded perforce in the direction of amiens street railway terminus, mr bloom being handicapped by the circumstance that one of the back buttons of his trousers had, to vary the timehonoured adage, gone the way of all buttons, though, entering thoroughly into the spirit of the thing, he heroically made light of the mischance. so, as neither of them were particularly pressed for time, as it happened, and the temperature refreshing since it cleared up after the recent visitation of jupiter pluvius, they dandered along past by where the empty vehicle was waiting without a fare or a jarvey. as it so happened a dublin united tramways company's sandstrewer happening to be returning the elder man recounted to his companion à propos of the incident his own truly miraculous escape of some little while back. they passed the main entrance of the great northern railway station, the starting point for belfast, where of course all traffic was suspended at that late hour, and, passing the back door of the morgue (a not very enticing locality, not to say gruesome to a degree, more especially at night), ultimately gained the dock tavern and in due course turned into store street, famous for its c division police station. between this point and the high, at present unlit, warehouses of beresford place stephen thought to think of ibsen, associated with baird's, the stonecutter's, in his mind somehow in talbot place, first turning on the right, while the other, who was acting as his fidus achates, inhaled with internal satisfaction the smell of james rourke's city bakery, situated quite close to where they were, the very palatable odour indeed of our daily bread, of all commodities of the public the primary and most indispensable. bread, the staff of life, earn your bread, o tell me where is fancy bread? at rourke's the baker's, it is said. nl en route, to his taciturn, and, not to put too fine a point on it, not yet perfectly sober companion, mr bloom, who at all events, was in complete possession of his faculties, never more so, in fact disgustingly sober, spoke a word of caution re the dangers of nighttown, women of ill fame and swell mobsmen, which, barely permissible once in a while, though not as a habitual practice, was of the nature of a regular deathtrap for young fellows of his age particularly if they had acquired drinking habits under the influence of liquor unless you knew a little juijitsu for every contingency as even a fellow on the broad of his back could administer a nasty kick if you didn't look out. highly providential was the appearance on the scene of corny kelleher when stephen was blissfully unconscious that, but for that man in the gap turning up at the eleventh hour, the finis might have been that he might have been a candidate for the accident ward, or, failing that, the bridewell and an appearance in the court next day before mr tobias, or, he being the solicitor, rather old wall, he meant to say, or malony which simply spelt ruin for a chap when it got bruited about. the reason he mentioned the fact was that a lot of those policemen, whom he cordially disliked, were admittedly unscrupulous in the service of the crown and, as mr bloom put it, recalling a case or two in the a division in clanbrassil street, prepared to swear a hole through a ten gallon pot. never on the spot when wanted but in quiet parts of the city, pembroke road, for example, the guardians of the law were well in evidence, the obvious reason being they were paid to protect the upper classes. another thing he commented on was equipping soldiers with firearms or sidearms of any description, liable to go off at any time, which was tantamount to inciting them against civilians should by any chance they fall nut over anything. you frittered away your time, he very sensibly maintained, and health and also character besides which the squandermania of the thing, fast women of the demimonde ran away with a lot of #. s. d. into the bargain and the greatest danger of all was who you got drunk with though, touching the much vexed question of stimulants, he relished a glass of choice old wine in season as both nourishing and blood-making and possessing aperient virtues (notably a good burgundy which he was a staunch believer in) still never beyond a certain point where he invariably drew the line as it simply led to trouble all round to say nothing of your being at the tender mercy of others practically. most of all he commented adversely on the desertion of stephen by all his pubhunting confrères but one, a most glaring piece of ratting on the part of his brother medicos under all the circs. nl —and that one was judas, said stephen, who up to then had said nothing whatsoever of any kind. nl discussing these and kindred topics they made a beeline across the back of the customhouse and passed under the loop line bridge when a brazier of coke burning in front of a sentrybox, or something like one, attracted their rather lagging footsteps. stephen of his own accord stopped for no special reason to look at the heap of barren cobblestones and by the light emanating from the brazier he could just make out the darker figure of the corporation watchman inside the gloom of the sentrybox. he began to remember that this had happened, or had been mentioned as having happened, before but it cost him no small effort before he remembered that he recognised in the sentry a quondam friend of his father's gumley. to avoid a meeting be drew nearer to the pillars of the railway bridge. nl —someone saluted you, mr bloom said. nl a figure of middle height on the prowl, evidently, under the arches saluted again, calling: night! stephen, of course, started rather dizzily and stopped to return the compliment. mr bloom, actuated by motives of inherent delicacy, inasmuch as he always believed in minding his own business, moved off but nevertheless remained on the qui vive with just a shade of anxiety though not funkyish in the least. although unusual in the dublin area, he knew that it was not by any means unknown for desperadoes who had next to nothing to live on to be about waylaying and generally terrorising peaceable pedestrians by placing a pistol at their head in some secluded spot outside the city proper, famished loiterers of the thames embankment category they might be hanging about there or simply marauders ready to decamp with whatever boodle they could in one fell swoop at a moments notice, your money or your life, leaving you there to point a moral, gagged and garotted. nl stephen, that is when the accosting figure came to close quarters, though he was not in any over sober state himself, recognised corley's breath redolent of rotten cornjuice. lord john corley, some called him, and his genealogy came about in this wise. he was the eldest son of inspector corley of the g division, lately deceased, who had married a certain katherine brophy, the daughter of a louth farmer. his grandfather, patrick michael corley, of new ross, had married the widow of a publican there whose maiden name had been katherine (also) talbot. rumour had it, though not proved, that she descended from the house of the lords talbot de malahide in whose mansion, really an unquestionably fine residence of its kind and well worth seeing, his mother or aunt or some relative had enjoyed the distinction of being in service in the washkitchen. this, therefore, was the reason why the still comparatively young though dissolute man who now addressed stephen was spoken of by some with facetious proclivities as lord john corley. nl taking stephen on one side he had the customary doleful ditty to tell. not as much as a farthing to purchase a night's lodgings. his friends had all deserted him. furthermore, he had a row with lenehan and called him to stephen a mean bloody swab with a sprinkling of other uncalled-for expressions. he was out of a job and implored of stephen to tell him where on god's earth he could get something, anything at all to do. no, it was the daughter of the mother in the washkitchen that was fostersister to the heir of the house or else they were connected through the mother in some way, both occurrences happening at the same time if the whole thing wasn't a complete fabrication from start to finish. anyhow, he was ill in. nl —i wouldn't ask you, only, pursued he, on my solemn oath and god knows i'm on the rocks. nl —there'll be a job tomorrow or the next day, stephen told him, in a boys' school at dalkey for a gentleman usher. mr garret deasy. try it. you may mention my name. nl —ah, god, corley replied, sure i couldn't teach in a school, man. i was never one of your bright ones, he added with a half laugh. got stuck twice in the junior at the christian brothers. nl —i have no place to sleep myself, stephen informed him. nl corley, at the first go-off, was inclined to suspect it was something to do with stephen being fired out of his digs for bringing in a bloody tart off the street. there was a dosshouse in marlborough street, mrs maloney's, but it was only a tanner touch and full of undesirables but m'conachie told him you got a decent enough do in the brazen head over in winetavern street (which was distantly suggestive to the person addressed of friar bacon) for a bob. he was starving too though he hadn't said a word about it. nl though this sort of thing went on every other night or very near it still stephen's feelings got the better of him in a sense though he knew that corley's brandnew rigmarole, on a par with the others, was hardly deserving of much credence. however, haud ignarus malorum miseris succurrere disco, etcetera, as the latin poet remarks, especially as luck would have it he got paid his screw after every middle of the month on the sixteenth which was the date of the month as a matter of fact though a good bit of the wherewithal was demolished. but the cream of the joke was nothing would get it out of corley's head that he was living in affluence and hadn't a thing to do but hand out the needful - whereas. he put his hand in a pocket anyhow, not with the idea of finding any food there, but thinking he might lend him anything up to a bob or so in lieu so that he might endeavour at all events and get sufficient to eat. but the result was in the negative for, to his chagrin, he found his cash missing. a few broken biscuits were all the result of his investigation. he tried his hardest to recollect for the moment whether he had lost, as well he might have, or left, because in that contingency it was not a pleasant lookout, very much the reverse, in fact. he was altogether too fagged out to institute a thorough search though he tried to recollect about biscuits he dimly remembered. who now exactly gave them, or where was, or did he buy? however, in another pocket he came across what he surmised in the dark were pennies, erroneously, however, as it turned out. nl —those are halfcrowns, man, corley corrected him. nl and so in point of fact they turned out to be. stephen lent him one of them. nl —thanks, corley answered. you're a gentleman. i'll pay you back some time. who's that with you? i saw him a few times in the bleeding horse in camden street with boylan the billsticker. you might put in a good word for us to get me taken on there. i'd carry a sandwichboard only the girl in the office told me they're full up for the next three weeks, man. god, you've to book ahead, man, you'd think it was for the carl rosa. i don't give a shite anyway so long as i get a job even as a crossing sweeper. nl subsequently, being not quite so down in the mouth after the two-and-six he got, he informed stephen about a fellow by the name of bags comisky that he said stephen knew well out of fullam's, the shipchandler's bookkeeper there, that used to be often round in nagle's back with o'mara and a little chap with a stutter the name of tighe. anyhow, he was lagged the night before last and fined ten bob for a drunk and disorderly and refusing to go with the constable. nl mr bloom in the meanwhile kept dodging about in the vicinity of the cobblestones near the brazier of coke in front of the corporation watchman's sentrybox, who, evidently a glutton for work, it struck him, was having a quiet forty winks for all intents and purposes on his own private account while dublin slept. he threw an odd eye at the same time now and then at stephen's anything but immaculately attired interlocutor as if he had seen that nobleman somewhere or other though where he was not in a position to truthfully state nor had he the remotest idea when. being a levelheaded individual who could give points to not a few in point of shrewd observation, he also remarked on his very dilapidated hat and slouchy wearing apparel generally, testifying to a chronic impecuniosity. probably he was one of his hangerson but for the matter of that it was merely a question of one preying on his next door neighbour all round, in every deep, so to put it, a deeper depth and for the matter of that if the man in the street chanced to be in the dock himself penal servitude, with or without the option of a fine, would be a very rara avis altogether. in any case he had a consummate amount of cool assurance intercepting people at that hour of the night or morning. pretty thick that was certainly. nl the pair parted company and stephen rejoined mr bloom, who, with his practised eye, was not without perceiving that he had succumbed to the blandiloquence of the other parasite. alluding to the encounter he said, laughingly, stephen, that is: nl —he's down on his luck. he asked me to ask you to ask somebody named boylan, a billsticker, to give him a job as a sandwichman. nl at this intelligence, in which he seemingly evinced little interest, mr bloom gazed abstractedly for the space of a half a second or so in the direction of a bucket dredger, rejoicing in the farfamed name of eblana, moored alongside customhouse quay and quite possibly out of repair, whereupon he observed evasively: nl —everybody gets their own ration of luck, they say. now you mention it his face was familiar to me. but leaving that for the station. simply fag out there for nothing. i don't mean to presume to dictate to you in the slightest degree but why did you leave your father's house? nl —to seek misfortune, was stephen's answer. nl —i met your respected father on a recent occasion, mr bloom diplomatically returned. today, in fact, or, to be strictly accurate, on yesterday. where does he live at present? i gathered in the course mezzo sovrano più nl —dice lui, pero. nl —farabutto! mortacci sui! nl mr bloom and stephen entered the cabman's shelter, an unpretentious wooden structure, where, prior to then, he had rarely, if nl side by side bloom, profiting by the contretemps, with stephen passed through the gap of the chains, divided by the upright, and, stepping over a strand of mire, went across towards gardiner street lower, stephen singing more boldly, but not loudly, the end of the ballad. nl und alle schiffe brücken. nl the driver never said a word, good, bad or indifferent, but merely nl watched the two figures, as he sat on his lowbacked car, both black, one full, one lean, walk towards the railway bridge, to be married by father maher. as they walked they at times stopped and walked again continuing their téte à téte (which, of course, he was utterly out of) about sirens enemies of man's reason, mingled with a number of other topics of the same category, usurpers, historical cases of the kind while the man in the sweeper car or you might as well call it in the sleeper car who in any case couldn't possibly hear because they were too far simply sat in his seat near the end of lower gardiner street and looked after their lowbacked car.

i want a hero: an uncommon want, nl when every year and month sends forth a new one, nl till, after cloying the gazettes with cant, nl the age discovers he is not the true one; nl of such as these i should not care to vaunt, nl i'll therefore take our ancient friend don juan— nl we all have seen him, in the pantomime, nl sent to the devil somewhat ere his time. nl vernon, the butcher cumberland, wolfe, hawke, nl prince ferdinand, granby, burgoyne, keppel, howe, nl evil and good, have had their tithe of talk, nl and fill'd their sign posts then, like wellesley now; nl each in their turn like banquo's monarchs stalk, nl followers of fame, 'nine farrow' of that sow : nl france, too, had buonaparte and dumourier nl recorded in the moniteur and courier. nl barnave, brissot, condorcet, mirabeau, nl petion, clootz, danton, marat, la fayette, nl were french, and famous people, as we know: nl and there were others, scarce forgotten yet, nl joubert, hoche, marceau, lannes, desaix, moreau, nl with many of the military set, nl exceedingly remarkable at times, nl but not at all adapted to my rhymes. nl nelson was once britannia's god of war, nl and still should be so, but the tide is turn'd; nl there 's no more to be said of trafalgar, nl 't is with our hero quietly inurn'd; nl because the army 's grown more popular, nl at which the naval people are concern'd; nl besides, the prince is all for the land-service, nl forgetting duncan, nelson, howe, and jervis. nl brave men were living before agamemnon nl and since, exceeding valorous and sage, nl a good deal like him too, though quite the same none; nl but then they shone not on the poet's page, nl and so have been forgotten:—i condemn none, nl but can't find any in the present age nl fit for my poem (that is, for my new one); nl so, as i said, i 'll take my friend don juan. nl most epic poets plunge 'in medias res' nl (horace makes this the heroic turnpike road), nl and then your hero tells, whene'er you please, nl what went before—by way of episode, nl while seated after dinner at his ease, nl beside his mistress in some soft abode, nl palace, or garden, paradise, or cavern, nl which serves the happy couple for a tavern. nl that is the usual method, but not mine— nl my way is to begin with the beginning; nl the regularity of my design nl forbids all wandering as the worst of sinning, nl and therefore i shall open with a line nl (although it cost me half an hour in spinning) nl narrating somewhat of don juan's father, nl and also of his mother, if you 'd rather. nl in seville was he born, a pleasant city, nl famous for oranges and women—he nl who has not seen it will be much to pity, nl so says the proverb—and i quite agree; nl of all the spanish towns is none more pretty, nl cadiz perhaps—but that you soon may see; nl don juan's parents lived beside the river, nl a noble stream, and call'd the guadalquivir. nl his father's name was jose—don, of course,— nl a true hidalgo, free from every stain nl of moor or hebrew blood, he traced his source nl through the most gothic gentlemen of spain; nl a better cavalier ne'er mounted horse, nl or, being mounted, e'er got down again, nl than jose, who begot our hero, who nl begot—but that 's to come—well, to renew: nl his mother was a learned lady, famed nl for every branch of every science known nl in every christian language ever named, nl with virtues equall'd by her wit alone, nl she made the cleverest people quite ashamed, nl and even the good with inward envy groan, nl finding themselves so very much exceeded nl in their own way by all the things that she did. nl her memory was a mine: she knew by heart nl all calderon and greater part of lope, nl so that if any actor miss'd his part nl she could have served him for the prompter's copy; nl for her feinagle's were an useless art, nl and he himself obliged to shut up shop—he nl could never make a memory so fine as nl that which adorn'd the brain of donna inez. nl her favourite science was the mathematical, nl her noblest virtue was her magnanimity, nl her wit (she sometimes tried at wit) was attic all, nl her serious sayings darken'd to sublimity; nl in short, in all things she was fairly what i call nl a prodigy—her morning dress was dimity, nl her evening silk, or, in the summer, muslin, nl and other stuffs, with which i won't stay puzzling. nl she knew the latin—that is, 'the lord's prayer,' nl and greek—the alphabet—i 'm nearly sure; nl she read some french romances here and there, nl although her mode of speaking was not pure; nl for native spanish she had no great care, nl at least her conversation was obscure; nl her thoughts were theorems, her words a problem, nl as if she deem'd that mystery would ennoble 'em. nl she liked the english and the hebrew tongue, nl and said there was analogy between 'em; nl she proved it somehow out of sacred song, nl but i must leave the proofs to those who 've seen 'em; nl but this i heard her say, and can't be wrong nl and all may think which way their judgments lean 'em, nl ''t is strange—the hebrew noun which means "i am," nl the english always use to govern d--n.' nl some women use their tongues—she look'd a lecture, nl each eye a sermon, and her brow a homily, nl an all-in-all sufficient self-director, nl like the lamented late sir samuel romilly, nl the law's expounder, and the state's corrector, nl whose suicide was almost an anomaly— nl one sad example more, that 'all is vanity' nl (the jury brought their verdict in 'insanity'). nl in short, she was a walking calculation, nl miss edgeworth's novels stepping from their covers, nl or mrs. trimmer's books on education, nl or 'coelebs' wife' set out in quest of lovers, nl morality's prim personification, nl in which not envy's self a flaw discovers; nl to others' share let 'female errors fall,' nl for she had not even one—the worst of all. nl o! she was perfect past all parallel— nl of any modern female saint's comparison; nl so far above the cunning powers of hell, nl her guardian angel had given up his garrison; nl even her minutest motions went as well nl as those of the best time-piece made by harrison: nl in virtues nothing earthly could surpass her, nl save thine 'incomparable oil,' macassar! nl perfect she was, but as perfection is nl insipid in this naughty world of ours, nl where our first parents never learn'd to kiss nl till they were exiled from their earlier bowers, nl where all was peace, and innocence, and bliss nl (i wonder how they got through the twelve hours), nl don jose, like a lineal son of eve, nl went plucking various fruit without her leave. nl he was a mortal of the careless kind, nl with no great love for learning, or the learn'd, nl who chose to go where'er he had a mind, nl and never dream'd his lady was concern'd; nl the world, as usual, wickedly inclined nl to see a kingdom or a house o'erturn'd, nl whisper'd he had a mistress, some said two— nl but for domestic quarrels one will do. nl now donna inez had, with all her merit, nl a great opinion of her own good qualities; nl neglect, indeed, requires a saint to bear it, nl and such, indeed, she was in her moralities; nl but then she had a devil of a spirit, nl and sometimes mix'd up fancies with realities, nl and let few opportunities escape nl of getting her liege lord into a scrape. nl this was an easy matter with a man nl oft in the wrong, and never on his guard; nl and even the wisest, do the best they can, nl have moments, hours, and days, so unprepared, nl that you might 'brain them with their lady's fan;' nl and sometimes ladies hit exceeding hard, nl and fans turn into falchions in fair hands, nl and why and wherefore no one understands. nl 't is pity learned virgins ever wed nl with persons of no sort of education, nl or gentlemen, who, though well born and bred, nl grow tired of scientific conversation: nl i don't choose to say much upon this head, nl i'm a plain man, and in a single station, nl but—oh! ye lords of ladies intellectual, nl inform us truly, have they not hen-peck'd you all? nl don jose and his lady quarrell'd—why, nl not any of the many could divine, nl though several thousand people chose to try, nl 't was surely no concern of theirs nor mine; nl i loathe that low vice—curiosity; nl but if there 's anything in which i shine, nl 't is in arranging all my friends' affairs, nl not having of my own domestic cares. nl and so i interfered, and with the best nl intentions, but their treatment was not kind; nl i think the foolish people were possess'd, nl for neither of them could i ever find, nl although their porter afterwards confess'd— nl but that 's no matter, and the worst 's behind, nl for little juan o'er me threw, down stairs, nl a pail of housemaid's water unawares. nl a little curly-headed, good-for-nothing, nl and mischief-making monkey from his birth; nl his parents ne'er agreed except in doting nl upon the most unquiet imp on earth; nl instead of quarrelling, had they been but both in nl their senses, they 'd have sent young master forth nl to school, or had him soundly whipp'd at home, nl to teach him manners for the time to come. nl don jose and the donna inez led nl for some time an unhappy sort of life, nl wishing each other, not divorced, but dead; nl they lived respectably as man and wife, nl their conduct was exceedingly well-bred, nl and gave no outward signs of inward strife, nl until at length the smother'd fire broke out, nl and put the business past all kind of doubt. nl for inez call'd some druggists and physicians, nl and tried to prove her loving lord was mad; nl but as he had some lucid intermissions, nl she next decided he was only bad; nl yet when they ask'd her for her depositions, nl no sort of explanation could be had, nl save that her duty both to man and god nl required this conduct—which seem'd very odd. nl she kept a journal, where his faults were noted, nl and open'd certain trunks of books and letters, nl all which might, if occasion served, be quoted; nl and then she had all seville for abettors, nl besides her good old grandmother (who doted); nl the hearers of her case became repeaters, nl then advocates, inquisitors, and judges, nl some for amusement, others for old grudges. nl and then this best and weakest woman bore nl with such serenity her husband's woes, nl just as the spartan ladies did of yore, nl who saw their spouses kill'd, and nobly chose nl never to say a word about them more— nl calmly she heard each calumny that rose, nl and saw his agonies with such sublimity, nl that all the world exclaim'd, 'what magnanimity!' nl no doubt this patience, when the world is damning us, nl is philosophic in our former friends; nl 't is also pleasant to be deem'd magnanimous, nl the more so in obtaining our own ends; nl and what the lawyers call a 'malus animus' nl conduct like this by no means comprehends; nl revenge in person 's certainly no virtue, nl but then 't is not my fault, if others hurt you. nl and if your quarrels should rip up old stories, nl and help them with a lie or two additional, nl i 'm not to blame, as you well know—no more is nl any one else—they were become traditional; nl besides, their resurrection aids our glories nl by contrast, which is what we just were wishing all: nl and science profits by this resurrection— nl dead scandals form good subjects for dissection. nl their friends had tried at reconciliation, nl then their relations, who made matters worse. nl ('t were hard to tell upon a like occasion nl to whom it may be best to have recourse— nl i can't say much for friend or yet relation): nl the lawyers did their utmost for divorce, nl but scarce a fee was paid on either side nl before, unluckily, don jose died. nl he died: and most unluckily, because, nl according to all hints i could collect nl from counsel learned in those kinds of laws nl (although their talk 's obscure and circumspect), nl his death contrived to spoil a charming cause; nl a thousand pities also with respect nl to public feeling, which on this occasion nl was manifested in a great sensation. nl but, ah! he died; and buried with him lay nl the public feeling and the lawyers' fees: nl his house was sold, his servants sent away, nl a jew took one of his two mistresses, nl a priest the other—at least so they say: nl i ask'd the doctors after his disease— nl he died of the slow fever call'd the tertian, nl and left his widow to her own aversion. nl yet jose was an honourable man, nl that i must say who knew him very well; nl therefore his frailties i 'll no further scan nl indeed there were not many more to tell; nl and if his passions now and then outran nl discretion, and were not so peaceable nl as numa's (who was also named pompilius), nl he had been ill brought up, and was born bilious. nl whate'er might be his worthlessness or worth, nl poor fellow! he had many things to wound him. nl let 's own—since it can do no good on earth— nl it was a trying moment that which found him nl standing alone beside his desolate hearth, nl where all his household gods lay shiver'd round him: nl no choice was left his feelings or his pride, nl save death or doctors' commons—so he died. nl dying intestate, juan was sole heir nl to a chancery suit, and messuages, and lands, nl which, with a long minority and care, nl promised to turn out well in proper hands: nl inez became sole guardian, which was fair, nl and answer'd but to nature's just demands; nl an only son left with an only mother nl is brought up much more wisely than another. nl sagest of women, even of widows, she nl resolved that juan should be quite a paragon, nl and worthy of the noblest pedigree nl (his sire was of castile, his dam from aragon): nl then for accomplishments of chivalry, nl in case our lord the king should go to war again, nl he learn'd the arts of riding, fencing, gunnery, nl and how to scale a fortress—or a nunnery. nl but that which donna inez most desired, nl and saw into herself each day before all nl the learned tutors whom for him she hired, nl was, that his breeding should be strictly moral; nl much into all his studies she inquired, nl and so they were submitted first to her, all, nl arts, sciences, no branch was made a mystery nl to juan's eyes, excepting natural history. nl the languages, especially the dead, nl the sciences, and most of all the abstruse, nl the arts, at least all such as could be said nl to be the most remote from common use, nl in all these he was much and deeply read; nl but not a page of any thing that 's loose, nl or hints continuation of the species, nl was ever suffer'd, lest he should grow vicious. nl his classic studies made a little puzzle, nl because of filthy loves of gods and goddesses, nl who in the earlier ages raised a bustle, nl but never put on pantaloons or bodices; nl his reverend tutors had at times a tussle, nl and for their aeneids, iliads, and odysseys, nl were forced to make an odd sort of apology, nl for donna inez dreaded the mythology. nl ovid 's a rake, as half his verses show him, nl anacreon's morals are a still worse sample, nl catullus scarcely has a decent poem, nl i don't think sappho's ode a good example, nl although longinus tells us there is no hymn nl where the sublime soars forth on wings more ample: nl but virgil's songs are pure, except that horrid one nl beginning with 'formosum pastor corydon.' nl lucretius' irreligion is too strong, nl for early stomachs, to prove wholesome food; nl i can't help thinking juvenal was wrong, nl although no doubt his real intent was good, nl for speaking out so plainly in his song, nl so much indeed as to be downright rude; nl and then what proper person can be partial nl to all those nauseous epigrams of martial? nl juan was taught from out the best edition, nl expurgated by learned men, who place nl judiciously, from out the schoolboy's vision, nl the grosser parts; but, fearful to deface nl too much their modest bard by this omission, nl and pitying sore his mutilated case, nl they only add them all in an appendix, nl which saves, in fact, the trouble of an index; nl for there we have them all 'at one fell swoop,' nl instead of being scatter'd through the pages; nl they stand forth marshall'd in a handsome troop, nl to meet the ingenuous youth of future ages, nl till some less rigid editor shall stoop nl to call them back into their separate cages, nl instead of standing staring all together, nl like garden gods—and not so decent either. nl the missal too (it was the family missal) nl was ornamented in a sort of way nl which ancient mass-books often are, and this all nl kinds of grotesques illumined; and how they, nl who saw those figures on the margin kiss all, nl could turn their optics to the text and pray, nl is more than i know—but don juan's mother nl kept this herself, and gave her son another. nl sermons he read, and lectures he endured, nl and homilies, and lives of all the saints; nl to jerome and to chrysostom inured, nl he did not take such studies for restraints; nl but how faith is acquired, and then ensured, nl so well not one of the aforesaid paints nl as saint augustine in his fine confessions, nl which make the reader envy his transgressions. nl this, too, was a seal'd book to little juan— nl i can't but say that his mamma was right, nl if such an education was the true one. nl she scarcely trusted him from out her sight; nl her maids were old, and if she took a new one, nl you might be sure she was a perfect fright; nl she did this during even her husband's life— nl i recommend as much to every wife. nl young juan wax'd in goodliness and grace; nl at six a charming child, and at eleven nl with all the promise of as fine a face nl as e'er to man's maturer growth was given: nl he studied steadily, and grew apace, nl and seem'd, at least, in the right road to heaven, nl for half his days were pass'd at church, the other nl between his tutors, confessor, and mother. nl at six, i said, he was a charming child, nl at twelve he was a fine, but quiet boy; nl although in infancy a little wild, nl they tamed him down amongst them: to destroy nl his natural spirit not in vain they toil'd, nl at least it seem'd so; and his mother's joy nl was to declare how sage, and still, and steady, nl her young philosopher was grown already. nl i had my doubts, perhaps i have them still, nl but what i say is neither here nor there: nl i knew his father well, and have some skill nl in character—but it would not be fair nl from sire to son to augur good or ill: nl he and his wife were an ill-sorted pair— nl but scandal 's my aversion—i protest nl against all evil speaking, even in jest. nl for my part i say nothing—nothing—but nl this i will say—my reasons are my own— nl that if i had an only son to put nl to school (as god be praised that i have none), nl 't is not with donna inez i would shut nl him up to learn his catechism alone, nl no—no—i 'd send him out betimes to college, nl for there it was i pick'd up my own knowledge. nl for there one learns—'t is not for me to boast, nl though i acquired—but i pass over that, nl as well as all the greek i since have lost: nl i say that there 's the place—but 'verbum sat.' nl i think i pick'd up too, as well as most, nl knowledge of matters—but no matter what— nl i never married—but, i think, i know nl that sons should not be educated so. nl young juan now was sixteen years of age, nl tall, handsome, slender, but well knit: he seem'd nl active, though not so sprightly, as a page; nl and everybody but his mother deem'd nl him almost man; but she flew in a rage nl and bit her lips (for else she might have scream'd) nl if any said so, for to be precocious nl was in her eyes a thing the most atrocious. nl amongst her numerous acquaintance, all nl selected for discretion and devotion, nl there was the donna julia, whom to call nl pretty were but to give a feeble notion nl of many charms in her as natural nl as sweetness to the flower, or salt to ocean, nl her zone to venus, or his bow to cupid nl (but this last simile is trite and stupid). nl the darkness of her oriental eye nl accorded with her moorish origin nl (her blood was not all spanish, by the by; nl in spain, you know, this is a sort of sin); nl when proud granada fell, and, forced to fly, nl boabdil wept, of donna julia's kin nl some went to africa, some stay'd in spain, nl her great-great-grandmamma chose to remain. nl she married (i forget the pedigree) nl with an hidalgo, who transmitted down nl his blood less noble than such blood should be; nl at such alliances his sires would frown, nl in that point so precise in each degree nl that they bred in and in, as might be shown, nl marrying their cousins—nay, their aunts, and nieces, nl which always spoils the breed, if it increases. nl this heathenish cross restored the breed again, nl ruin'd its blood, but much improved its flesh; nl for from a root the ugliest in old spain nl sprung up a branch as beautiful as fresh; nl the sons no more were short, the daughters plain: nl but there 's a rumour which i fain would hush, nl 't is said that donna julia's grandmamma nl produced her don more heirs at love than law. nl however this might be, the race went on nl improving still through every generation, nl until it centred in an only son, nl who left an only daughter; my narration nl may have suggested that this single one nl could be but julia (whom on this occasion nl i shall have much to speak about), and she nl was married, charming, chaste, and twenty-three. nl her eye (i 'm very fond of handsome eyes) nl was large and dark, suppressing half its fire nl until she spoke, then through its soft disguise nl flash'd an expression more of pride than ire, nl and love than either; and there would arise nl a something in them which was not desire, nl but would have been, perhaps, but for the soul nl which struggled through and chasten'd down the whole. nl her glossy hair was cluster'd o'er a brow nl bright with intelligence, and fair, and smooth; nl her eyebrow's shape was like th' aerial bow, nl her cheek all purple with the beam of youth, nl mounting at times to a transparent glow, nl as if her veins ran lightning; she, in sooth, nl possess'd an air and grace by no means common: nl her stature tall—i hate a dumpy woman. nl wedded she was some years, and to a man nl of fifty, and such husbands are in plenty; nl and yet, i think, instead of such a one nl 't were better to have two of five-and-twenty, nl especially in countries near the sun: nl and now i think on 't, 'mi vien in mente,' nl ladies even of the most uneasy virtue nl prefer a spouse whose age is short of thirty. nl 't is a sad thing, i cannot choose but say, nl and all the fault of that indecent sun, nl who cannot leave alone our helpless clay, nl but will keep baking, broiling, burning on, nl that howsoever people fast and pray, nl the flesh is frail, and so the soul undone: nl what men call gallantry, and gods adultery, nl is much more common where the climate 's sultry. nl happy the nations of the moral north! nl where all is virtue, and the winter season nl sends sin, without a rag on, shivering forth nl ('t was snow that brought st. anthony to reason); nl where juries cast up what a wife is worth, nl by laying whate'er sum in mulct they please on nl the lover, who must pay a handsome price, nl because it is a marketable vice. nl alfonso was the name of julia's lord, nl a man well looking for his years, and who nl was neither much beloved nor yet abhorr'd: nl they lived together, as most people do, nl suffering each other's foibles by accord, nl and not exactly either one or two; nl yet he was jealous, though he did not show it, nl for jealousy dislikes the world to know it. nl julia was—yet i never could see why— nl with donna inez quite a favourite friend; nl between their tastes there was small sympathy, nl for not a line had julia ever penn'd: nl some people whisper but no doubt they lie, nl for malice still imputes some private end, nl that inez had, ere don alfonso's marriage, nl forgot with him her very prudent carriage; nl and that still keeping up the old connection, nl which time had lately render'd much more chaste, nl she took his lady also in affection, nl and certainly this course was much the best: nl she flatter'd julia with her sage protection, nl and complimented don alfonso's taste; nl and if she could not (who can?) silence scandal, nl at least she left it a more slender handle. nl i can't tell whether julia saw the affair nl with other people's eyes, or if her own nl discoveries made, but none could be aware nl of this, at least no symptom e'er was shown; nl perhaps she did not know, or did not care, nl indifferent from the first or callous grown: nl i 'm really puzzled what to think or say, nl she kept her counsel in so close a way. nl juan she saw, and, as a pretty child, nl caress'd him often—such a thing might be nl quite innocently done, and harmless styled, nl when she had twenty years, and thirteen he; nl but i am not so sure i should have smiled nl when he was sixteen, julia twenty-three; nl these few short years make wondrous alterations, nl particularly amongst sun-burnt nations. nl whate'er the cause might be, they had become nl changed; for the dame grew distant, the youth shy, nl their looks cast down, their greetings almost dumb, nl and much embarrassment in either eye; nl there surely will be little doubt with some nl that donna julia knew the reason why, nl but as for juan, he had no more notion nl than he who never saw the sea of ocean. nl yet julia's very coldness still was kind, nl and tremulously gentle her small hand nl withdrew itself from his, but left behind nl a little pressure, thrilling, and so bland nl and slight, so very slight, that to the mind nl 't was but a doubt; but ne'er magician's wand nl wrought change with all armida's fairy art nl like what this light touch left on juan's heart. nl and if she met him, though she smiled no more, nl she look'd a sadness sweeter than her smile, nl as if her heart had deeper thoughts in store nl she must not own, but cherish'd more the while nl for that compression in its burning core; nl even innocence itself has many a wile, nl and will not dare to trust itself with truth, nl and love is taught hypocrisy from youth. nl but passion most dissembles, yet betrays nl even by its darkness; as the blackest sky nl foretells the heaviest tempest, it displays nl its workings through the vainly guarded eye, nl and in whatever aspect it arrays nl itself, 't is still the same hypocrisy; nl coldness or anger, even disdain or hate, nl are masks it often wears, and still too late. nl then there were sighs, the deeper for suppression, nl and stolen glances, sweeter for the theft, nl and burning blushes, though for no transgression, nl tremblings when met, and restlessness when left; nl all these are little preludes to possession, nl of which young passion cannot be bereft, nl and merely tend to show how greatly love is nl embarrass'd at first starting with a novice. nl poor julia's heart was in an awkward state; nl she felt it going, and resolved to make nl the noblest efforts for herself and mate, nl for honour's, pride's, religion's, virtue's sake; nl her resolutions were most truly great, nl and almost might have made a tarquin quake: nl she pray'd the virgin mary for her grace, nl as being the best judge of a lady's case. nl she vow'd she never would see juan more, nl and next day paid a visit to his mother, nl and look'd extremely at the opening door, nl which, by the virgin's grace, let in another; nl grateful she was, and yet a little sore— nl again it opens, it can be no other, nl 't is surely juan now—no! i 'm afraid nl that night the virgin was no further pray'd. nl she now determined that a virtuous woman nl should rather face and overcome temptation, nl that flight was base and dastardly, and no man nl should ever give her heart the least sensation; nl that is to say, a thought beyond the common nl preference, that we must feel upon occasion nl for people who are pleasanter than others, nl but then they only seem so many brothers. nl and even if by chance—and who can tell? nl the devil 's so very sly—she should discover nl that all within was not so very well, nl and, if still free, that such or such a lover nl might please perhaps, a virtuous wife can quell nl such thoughts, and be the better when they 're over; nl and if the man should ask, 't is but denial: nl i recommend young ladies to make trial. nl and then there are such things as love divine, nl bright and immaculate, unmix'd and pure, nl such as the angels think so very fine, nl and matrons who would be no less secure, nl platonic, perfect, 'just such love as mine;' nl thus julia said—and thought so, to be sure; nl and so i 'd have her think, were i the man nl on whom her reveries celestial ran. nl such love is innocent, and may exist nl between young persons without any danger. nl a hand may first, and then a lip be kist; nl for my part, to such doings i 'm a stranger, nl but hear these freedoms form the utmost list nl of all o'er which such love may be a ranger: nl if people go beyond, 't is quite a crime, nl but not my fault—i tell them all in time. nl love, then, but love within its proper limits, nl was julia's innocent determination nl in young don juan's favour, and to him its nl exertion might be useful on occasion; nl and, lighted at too pure a shrine to dim its nl ethereal lustre, with what sweet persuasion nl he might be taught, by love and her together— nl i really don't know what, nor julia either. nl fraught with this fine intention, and well fenced nl in mail of proof—her purity of soul— nl she, for the future of her strength convinced. nl and that her honour was a rock, or mole, nl exceeding sagely from that hour dispensed nl with any kind of troublesome control; nl but whether julia to the task was equal nl is that which must be mention'd in the sequel. nl her plan she deem'd both innocent and feasible, nl and, surely, with a stripling of sixteen nl not scandal's fangs could fix on much that 's seizable, nl or if they did so, satisfied to mean nl nothing but what was good, her breast was peaceable— nl a quiet conscience makes one so serene! nl christians have burnt each other, quite persuaded nl that all the apostles would have done as they did. nl and if in the mean time her husband died, nl but heaven forbid that such a thought should cross nl her brain, though in a dream! (and then she sigh'd) nl never could she survive that common loss; nl but just suppose that moment should betide, nl i only say suppose it—inter nos. nl (this should be entre nous, for julia thought nl in french, but then the rhyme would go for naught.) nl i only say suppose this supposition: nl juan being then grown up to man's estate nl would fully suit a widow of condition, nl even seven years hence it would not be too late; nl and in the interim (to pursue this vision) nl the mischief, after all, could not be great, nl for he would learn the rudiments of love, nl i mean the seraph way of those above. nl so much for julia. now we 'll turn to juan. nl poor little fellow! he had no idea nl of his own case, and never hit the true one; nl in feelings quick as ovid's miss medea, nl he puzzled over what he found a new one, nl but not as yet imagined it could be nl thing quite in course, and not at all alarming, nl which, with a little patience, might grow charming. nl silent and pensive, idle, restless, slow, nl his home deserted for the lonely wood, nl tormented with a wound he could not know, nl his, like all deep grief, plunged in solitude: nl i 'm fond myself of solitude or so, nl but then, i beg it may be understood, nl by solitude i mean a sultan's, not nl a hermit's, with a haram for a grot. nl 'oh love! in such a wilderness as this, nl where transport and security entwine, nl here is the empire of thy perfect bliss, nl and here thou art a god indeed divine.' nl the bard i quote from does not sing amiss, nl with the exception of the second line, nl for that same twining 'transport and security' nl are twisted to a phrase of some obscurity. nl the poet meant, no doubt, and thus appeals nl to the good sense and senses of mankind, nl the very thing which every body feels, nl as all have found on trial, or may find, nl that no one likes to be disturb'd at meals nl or love.—i won't say more about 'entwined' nl or 'transport,' as we knew all that before, nl but beg 'security' will bolt the door. nl young juan wander'd by the glassy brooks, nl thinking unutterable things; he threw nl himself at length within the leafy nooks nl where the wild branch of the cork forest grew; nl there poets find materials for their books, nl and every now and then we read them through, nl so that their plan and prosody are eligible, nl unless, like wordsworth, they prove unintelligible. nl he, juan (and not wordsworth), so pursued nl his self-communion with his own high soul, nl until his mighty heart, in its great mood, nl had mitigated part, though not the whole nl of its disease; he did the best he could nl with things not very subject to control, nl and turn'd, without perceiving his condition, nl like coleridge, into a metaphysician. nl he thought about himself, and the whole earth nl of man the wonderful, and of the stars, nl and how the deuce they ever could have birth; nl and then he thought of earthquakes, and of wars, nl how many miles the moon might have in girth, nl of air-balloons, and of the many bars nl to perfect knowledge of the boundless skies;— nl and then he thought of donna julia's eyes. nl in thoughts like these true wisdom may discern nl longings sublime, and aspirations high, nl which some are born with, but the most part learn nl to plague themselves withal, they know not why: nl 't was strange that one so young should thus concern nl his brain about the action of the sky; nl if you think 't was philosophy that this did, nl i can't help thinking puberty assisted. nl he pored upon the leaves, and on the flowers, nl and heard a voice in all the winds; and then nl he thought of wood-nymphs and immortal bowers, nl and how the goddesses came down to men: nl he miss'd the pathway, he forgot the hours, nl and when he look'd upon his watch again, nl he found how much old time had been a winner— nl he also found that he had lost his dinner. nl sometimes he turn'd to gaze upon his book, nl boscan, or garcilasso;—by the wind nl even as the page is rustled while we look, nl so by the poesy of his own mind nl over the mystic leaf his soul was shook, nl as if 't were one whereon magicians bind nl their spells, and give them to the passing gale, nl according to some good old woman's tale. nl thus would he while his lonely hours away nl dissatisfied, nor knowing what he wanted; nl nor glowing reverie, nor poet's lay, nl could yield his spirit that for which it panted, nl a bosom whereon he his head might lay, nl and hear the heart beat with the love it granted, nl with—several other things, which i forget, nl or which, at least, i need not mention yet. nl those lonely walks, and lengthening reveries, nl could not escape the gentle julia's eyes; nl she saw that juan was not at his ease; nl but that which chiefly may, and must surprise, nl is, that the donna inez did not tease nl her only son with question or surmise: nl whether it was she did not see, or would not, nl or, like all very clever people, could not. nl this may seem strange, but yet 't is very common; nl for instance—gentlemen, whose ladies take nl leave to o'erstep the written rights of woman, nl and break the—which commandment is 't they break? nl (i have forgot the number, and think no man nl should rashly quote, for fear of a mistake.) nl i say, when these same gentlemen are jealous, nl they make some blunder, which their ladies tell us. nl a real husband always is suspicious, nl but still no less suspects in the wrong place, nl jealous of some one who had no such wishes, nl or pandering blindly to his own disgrace, nl by harbouring some dear friend extremely vicious; nl the last indeed 's infallibly the case: nl and when the spouse and friend are gone off wholly, nl he wonders at their vice, and not his folly. nl thus parents also are at times short-sighted; nl though watchful as the lynx, they ne'er discover, nl the while the wicked world beholds delighted, nl young hopeful's mistress, or miss fanny's lover, nl till some confounded escapade has blighted nl the plan of twenty years, and all is over; nl and then the mother cries, the father swears, nl and wonders why the devil he got heirs. nl but inez was so anxious, and so clear nl of sight, that i must think, on this occasion, nl she had some other motive much more near nl for leaving juan to this new temptation; nl but what that motive was, i sha'n't say here; nl perhaps to finish juan's education, nl perhaps to open don alfonso's eyes, nl in case he thought his wife too great a prize. nl it was upon a day, a summer's day.— nl summer's indeed a very dangerous season, nl and so is spring about the end of may; nl the sun, no doubt, is the prevailing reason; nl but whatsoe'er the cause is, one may say, nl and stand convicted of more truth than treason, nl that there are months which nature grows more merry in,— nl march has its hares, and may must have its heroine. nl 't was on a summer's day—the sixth of june:— nl i like to be particular in dates, nl not only of the age, and year, but moon; nl they are a sort of post-house, where the fates nl change horses, making history change its tune, nl then spur away o'er empires and o'er states, nl leaving at last not much besides chronology, nl excepting the post-obits of theology. nl 't was on the sixth of june, about the hour nl of half-past six—perhaps still nearer seven— nl when julia sate within as pretty a bower nl as e'er held houri in that heathenish heaven nl described by mahomet, and anacreon moore, nl to whom the lyre and laurels have been given, nl with all the trophies of triumphant song— nl he won them well, and may he wear them long! nl she sate, but not alone; i know not well nl how this same interview had taken place, nl and even if i knew, i should not tell— nl people should hold their tongues in any case; nl no matter how or why the thing befell, nl but there were she and juan, face to face— nl when two such faces are so, 't would be wise, nl but very difficult, to shut their eyes. nl how beautiful she look'd! her conscious heart nl glow'd in her cheek, and yet she felt no wrong. nl o love! how perfect is thy mystic art, nl strengthening the weak, and trampling on the strong, nl how self-deceitful is the sagest part nl of mortals whom thy lure hath led along— nl the precipice she stood on was immense, nl so was her creed in her own innocence. nl she thought of her own strength, and juan's youth, nl and of the folly of all prudish fears, nl victorious virtue, and domestic truth, nl and then of don alfonso's fifty years: nl i wish these last had not occurr'd, in sooth, nl because that number rarely much endears, nl and through all climes, the snowy and the sunny, nl sounds ill in love, whate'er it may in money. nl when people say, 'i've told you fifty times,' nl they mean to scold, and very often do; nl when poets say, 'i've written fifty rhymes,' nl they make you dread that they 'll recite them too; nl in gangs of fifty, thieves commit their crimes; nl at fifty love for love is rare, 't is true, nl but then, no doubt, it equally as true is, nl a good deal may be bought for fifty louis. nl julia had honour, virtue, truth, and love, nl for don alfonso; and she inly swore, nl by all the vows below to powers above, nl she never would disgrace the ring she wore, nl nor leave a wish which wisdom might reprove; nl and while she ponder'd this, besides much more, nl one hand on juan's carelessly was thrown, nl quite by mistake—she thought it was her own; nl unconsciously she lean'd upon the other, nl which play'd within the tangles of her hair: nl and to contend with thoughts she could not smother nl she seem'd by the distraction of her air. nl 't was surely very wrong in juan's mother nl to leave together this imprudent pair, nl she who for many years had watch'd her son so— nl i 'm very certain mine would not have done so. nl the hand which still held juan's, by degrees nl gently, but palpably confirm'd its grasp, nl as if it said, 'detain me, if you please;' nl yet there 's no doubt she only meant to clasp nl his fingers with a pure platonic squeeze: nl she would have shrunk as from a toad, or asp, nl had she imagined such a thing could rouse nl a feeling dangerous to a prudent spouse. nl i cannot know what juan thought of this, nl but what he did, is much what you would do; nl his young lip thank'd it with a grateful kiss, nl and then, abash'd at its own joy, withdrew nl in deep despair, lest he had done amiss,— nl love is so very timid when 't is new: nl she blush'd, and frown'd not, but she strove to speak, nl and held her tongue, her voice was grown so weak. nl the sun set, and up rose the yellow moon: nl the devil 's in the moon for mischief; they nl who call'd her chaste, methinks, began too soon nl their nomenclature; there is not a day, nl the longest, not the twenty-first of june, nl sees half the business in a wicked way nl on which three single hours of moonshine smile— nl and then she looks so modest all the while. nl there is a dangerous silence in that hour, nl a stillness, which leaves room for the full soul nl to open all itself, without the power nl of calling wholly back its self-control; nl the silver light which, hallowing tree and tower, nl sheds beauty and deep softness o'er the whole, nl breathes also to the heart, and o'er it throws nl a loving languor, which is not repose. nl and julia sate with juan, half embraced nl and half retiring from the glowing arm, nl which trembled like the bosom where 't was placed; nl yet still she must have thought there was no harm, nl or else 't were easy to withdraw her waist; nl but then the situation had its charm, nl and then—god knows what next—i can't go on; nl i 'm almost sorry that i e'er begun. nl o plato! plato! you have paved the way, nl with your confounded fantasies, to more nl immoral conduct by the fancied sway nl your system feigns o'er the controulless core nl of human hearts, than all the long array nl of poets and romancers:—you 're a bore, nl a charlatan, a coxcomb—and have been, nl at best, no better than a go-between. nl and julia's voice was lost, except in sighs, nl until too late for useful conversation; nl the tears were gushing from her gentle eyes, nl i wish indeed they had not had occasion, nl but who, alas! can love, and then be wise? nl not that remorse did not oppose temptation; nl a little still she strove, and much repented nl and whispering 'i will ne'er consent'—consented. nl 't is said that xerxes offer'd a reward nl to those who could invent him a new pleasure: nl methinks the requisition 's rather hard, nl and must have cost his majesty a treasure: nl for my part, i 'm a moderate-minded bard, nl fond of a little love (which i call leisure); nl i care not for new pleasures, as the old nl are quite enough for me, so they but hold. nl o pleasure! you are indeed a pleasant thing, nl although one must be damn'd for you, no doubt: nl i make a resolution every spring nl of reformation, ere the year run out, nl but somehow, this my vestal vow takes wing, nl yet still, i trust it may be kept throughout: nl i 'm very sorry, very much ashamed, nl and mean, next winter, to be quite reclaim'd. nl here my chaste muse a liberty must take— nl start not! still chaster reader—she 'll be nice hence— nl forward, and there is no great cause to quake; nl this liberty is a poetic licence, nl which some irregularity may make nl in the design, and as i have a high sense nl of aristotle and the rules, 't is fit nl to beg his pardon when i err a bit. nl this licence is to hope the reader will nl suppose from june the sixth (the fatal day, nl without whose epoch my poetic skill nl for want of facts would all be thrown away), nl but keeping julia and don juan still nl in sight, that several months have pass'd; we 'll say nl 't was in november, but i 'm not so sure nl about the day—the era 's more obscure. nl we 'll talk of that anon.—'t is sweet to hear nl at midnight on the blue and moonlit deep nl the song and oar of adria's gondolier, nl by distance mellow'd, o'er the waters sweep; nl 't is sweet to see the evening star appear; nl 't is sweet to listen as the night-winds creep nl from leaf to leaf; 't is sweet to view on high nl the rainbow, based on ocean, span the sky. nl 't is sweet to hear the watch-dog's honest bark nl bay deep-mouth'd welcome as we draw near home; nl 't is sweet to know there is an eye will mark nl our coming, and look brighter when we come; nl 't is sweet to be awaken'd by the lark, nl or lull'd by falling waters; sweet the hum nl of bees, the voice of girls, the song of birds, nl the lisp of children, and their earliest words. nl sweet is the vintage, when the showering grapes nl in bacchanal profusion reel to earth, nl purple and gushing: sweet are our escapes nl from civic revelry to rural mirth; nl sweet to the miser are his glittering heaps, nl sweet to the father is his first-born's birth, nl sweet is revenge—especially to women, nl pillage to soldiers, prize-money to seamen. nl sweet is a legacy, and passing sweet nl the unexpected death of some old lady nl or gentleman of seventy years complete, nl who 've made 'us youth' wait too—too long already nl for an estate, or cash, or country seat, nl still breaking, but with stamina so steady nl that all the israelites are fit to mob its nl next owner for their double-damn'd post-obits. nl 't is sweet to win, no matter how, one's laurels, nl by blood or ink; 't is sweet to put an end nl to strife; 't is sometimes sweet to have our quarrels, nl particularly with a tiresome friend: nl sweet is old wine in bottles, ale in barrels; nl dear is the helpless creature we defend nl against the world; and dear the schoolboy spot nl we ne'er forget, though there we are forgot. nl but sweeter still than this, than these, than all, nl is first and passionate love—it stands alone, nl like adam's recollection of his fall; nl the tree of knowledge has been pluck'd—all 's known— nl and life yields nothing further to recall nl worthy of this ambrosial sin, so shown, nl no doubt in fable, as the unforgiven nl fire which prometheus filch'd for us from heaven. nl man 's a strange animal, and makes strange use nl of his own nature, and the various arts, nl and likes particularly to produce nl some new experiment to show his parts; nl this is the age of oddities let loose, nl where different talents find their different marts; nl you 'd best begin with truth, and when you 've lost your nl labour, there 's a sure market for imposture. nl what opposite discoveries we have seen! nl (signs of true genius, and of empty pockets.) nl one makes new noses, one a guillotine, nl one breaks your bones, one sets them in their sockets; nl but vaccination certainly has been nl a kind antithesis to congreve's rockets, nl with which the doctor paid off an old pox, nl by borrowing a new one from an ox. nl bread has been made (indifferent) from potatoes; nl and galvanism has set some corpses grinning, nl but has not answer'd like the apparatus nl of the humane society's beginning nl by which men are unsuffocated gratis: nl what wondrous new machines have late been spinning! nl i said the small-pox has gone out of late; nl perhaps it may be follow'd by the great. nl 't is said the great came from america; nl perhaps it may set out on its return,— nl the population there so spreads, they say nl 't is grown high time to thin it in its turn, nl with war, or plague, or famine, any way, nl so that civilisation they may learn; nl and which in ravage the more loathsome evil is— nl their real lues, or our pseudo-syphilis? nl this is the patent-age of new inventions nl for killing bodies, and for saving souls, nl all propagated with the best intentions; nl sir humphry davy's lantern, by which coals nl are safely mined for in the mode he mentions, nl tombuctoo travels, voyages to the poles, nl are ways to benefit mankind, as true, nl perhaps, as shooting them at waterloo. nl man 's a phenomenon, one knows not what, nl and wonderful beyond all wondrous measure; nl 't is pity though, in this sublime world, that nl pleasure 's a sin, and sometimes sin 's a pleasure; nl few mortals know what end they would be at, nl but whether glory, power, or love, or treasure, nl the path is through perplexing ways, and when nl the goal is gain'd, we die, you know—and then— nl what then?—i do not know, no more do you— nl and so good night.—return we to our story: nl 't was in november, when fine days are few, nl and the far mountains wax a little hoary, nl and clap a white cape on their mantles blue; nl and the sea dashes round the promontory, nl and the loud breaker boils against the rock, nl and sober suns must set at five o'clock. nl 't was, as the watchmen say, a cloudy night; nl no moon, no stars, the wind was low or loud nl by gusts, and many a sparkling hearth was bright nl with the piled wood, round which the family crowd; nl there 's something cheerful in that sort of light, nl even as a summer sky 's without a cloud: nl i 'm fond of fire, and crickets, and all that, nl a lobster salad, and champagne, and chat. nl 't was midnight—donna julia was in bed, nl sleeping, most probably,—when at her door nl arose a clatter might awake the dead, nl if they had never been awoke before, nl and that they have been so we all have read, nl and are to be so, at the least, once more.-- nl the door was fasten'd, but with voice and fist nl first knocks were heard, then 'madam—madam—hist! nl 'for god's sake, madam—madam—here 's my master, nl with more than half the city at his back— nl was ever heard of such a curst disaster! nl 't is not my fault—i kept good watch—alack! nl do pray undo the bolt a little faster— nl they 're on the stair just now, and in a crack nl will all be here; perhaps he yet may fly— nl surely the window 's not so very high!' nl by this time don alfonso was arrived, nl with torches, friends, and servants in great number; nl the major part of them had long been wived, nl and therefore paused not to disturb the slumber nl of any wicked woman, who contrived nl by stealth her husband's temples to encumber: nl examples of this kind are so contagious, nl were one not punish'd, all would be outrageous. nl i can't tell how, or why, or what suspicion nl could enter into don alfonso's head; nl but for a cavalier of his condition nl it surely was exceedingly ill-bred, nl without a word of previous admonition, nl to hold a levee round his lady's bed, nl and summon lackeys, arm'd with fire and sword, nl to prove himself the thing he most abhorr'd. nl poor donna julia, starting as from sleep nl (mind—that i do not say—she had not slept), nl began at once to scream, and yawn, and weep; nl her maid antonia, who was an adept, nl contrived to fling the bed-clothes in a heap, nl as if she had just now from out them crept: nl i can't tell why she should take all this trouble nl to prove her mistress had been sleeping double. nl but julia mistress, and antonia maid, nl appear'd like two poor harmless women, who nl of goblins, but still more of men afraid, nl had thought one man might be deterr'd by two, nl and therefore side by side were gently laid, nl until the hours of absence should run through, nl and truant husband should return, and say, nl 'my dear, i was the first who came away.' nl now julia found at length a voice, and cried, nl 'in heaven's name, don alfonso, what d' ye mean? nl has madness seized you? would that i had died nl ere such a monster's victim i had been! nl what may this midnight violence betide, nl a sudden fit of drunkenness or spleen? nl dare you suspect me, whom the thought would kill? nl search, then, the room!'—alfonso said, 'i will.' nl he search'd, they search'd, and rummaged everywhere, nl closet and clothes' press, chest and window-seat, nl and found much linen, lace, and several pair nl of stockings, slippers, brushes, combs, complete, nl with other articles of ladies fair, nl to keep them beautiful, or leave them neat: nl arras they prick'd and curtains with their swords, nl and wounded several shutters, and some boards. nl under the bed they search'd, and there they found— nl no matter what—it was not that they sought; nl they open'd windows, gazing if the ground nl had signs or footmarks, but the earth said nought; nl and then they stared each other's faces round: nl 't is odd, not one of all these seekers thought, nl and seems to me almost a sort of blunder, nl of looking in the bed as well as under. nl during this inquisition, julia's tongue nl was not asleep—'yes, search and search,' she cried, nl 'insult on insult heap, and wrong on wrong! nl it was for this that i became a bride! nl for this in silence i have suffer'd long nl a husband like alfonso at my side; nl but now i 'll bear no more, nor here remain, nl if there be law or lawyers in all spain. nl 'yes, don alfonso! husband now no more, nl if ever you indeed deserved the name, nl is 't worthy of your years?—you have threescore— nl fifty, or sixty, it is all the same— nl is 't wise or fitting, causeless to explore nl for facts against a virtuous woman's fame? nl ungrateful, perjured, barbarous don alfonso, nl how dare you think your lady would go on so? nl 'is it for this i have disdain'd to hold nl the common privileges of my sex? nl that i have chosen a confessor so old nl and deaf, that any other it would vex, nl and never once he has had cause to scold, nl but found my very innocence perplex nl so much, he always doubted i was married— nl how sorry you will be when i 've miscarried! nl 'was it for this that no cortejo e'er nl i yet have chosen from out the youth of seville? nl is it for this i scarce went anywhere, nl except to bull-fights, mass, play, rout, and revel? nl is it for this, whate'er my suitors were, nl i favor'd none—nay, was almost uncivil? nl is it for this that general count o'reilly, nl who took algiers, declares i used him vilely? nl 'did not the italian musico cazzani nl sing at my heart six months at least in vain? nl did not his countryman, count corniani, nl call me the only virtuous wife in spain? nl were there not also russians, english, many? nl the count strongstroganoff i put in pain, nl and lord mount coffeehouse, the irish peer, nl who kill'd himself for love (with wine) last year. nl 'have i not had two bishops at my feet, nl the duke of ichar, and don fernan nunez? nl and is it thus a faithful wife you treat? nl i wonder in what quarter now the moon is: nl i praise your vast forbearance not to beat nl me also, since the time so opportune is— nl o, valiant man! with sword drawn and cock'd
